awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Demonstration of a Liquid Piston Gas Compressor/Expander for Compressed Air Energy Storage and CO2 Sequestration
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project is in advancing the development of a high efficiency, high power, high pressure gas compressor/expander. Such a device is key to enabling Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) to be used as a viable, economical electricity storage approach that can be deployed anywhere. Such an energy storage system can be used to save surplus electricity that would otherwise be waster to be used when demand is high. Also, as intermittent renewable energy resources such as wind and solar supply a larger portion of the electricity supply, energy storage is needed to supplement these resources when they are not available. The gas compressor can also be used for compressing other gases, such as carbon dioxide and gases used in many industries, with less energy consumption. The reduction in energy consumption and greenhouse gases will consequently increase the energy security of the U.S. and help combat climate change. 

The proposed project will develop and validate the performance of a prototype device for compressing and expanding gas to and from a high pressure. High efficiency will be achieved if the compression and expansion processes occur at constant temperature. To attain both high efficiency and high power, the compressor/expander will incorporate design that augments heat transfer. The prototype design will be based upon prior fundamental research that has led to two orders of magnitude increase in power density without sacrificing efficiency. This project advances the technological know-how of compressing and expanding gases more efficiently. In particular, it makes advances on the technique of achieving isothermal compression/ expansion using a liquid piston augmented with porous media heat transfer. Although the fundamental benefits of this approach have been established in prior research, these benefits have not been realized in a device. This project fills the knowledge gaps that exist to create such a devices by providing insight and understanding on optimal system design, valving, sensing and control, and the management of liquid-gas interface, which are necessary to achieve continuous reciprocating operation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Long-duration energy storage is key to the integration of a significant amount of renewable energies into the electric grid. On the one hand, energy storage can be used to balance any discrepancies between supply (when renewable energy is available, typically during the night for wind energy) and demand (typically during the work days). On the other hand, and more importantly, energy storage can be used to quickly supplement power when intermittent renewable energy falls short. Currently, this latter role is fulfilled by so-called peaker plants that use fossil fuels, are expensive to construct and operate, and are slow to startup and shut down. 

Compressed air energy storage (CAES) stores energy by compressing air from the atmosphere to high pressure and regenerates energy by reversing the process. It is a potentially low-cost and environmentally benign approach toward energy storage. It is expected to have a near infinite cycle life and be 3-4 times lower in cost than lithium batteries. They would thus be highly desirable for long-duration, grid-scale energy storage. A critical element in CAES is an efficient, high-pressure, and power-dense air compressor and expander. Ideally, the air compression/expansion process should occur at a constant temperature to be efficient but this causes the process to be extremely slow, requiring a very large and bulky system to fulfill the power demand of the electric grid. 

This project proposes a novel compressor/expander technology that compresses/expands air near isothermally and rapidly. The approach uses a controllable liquid (water) piston to compress/expand the air above it, and a set of porous media to enhance heat transfer.  In addition, it incorporates an intensifier configuration to enable very fast initial compression without requiring very large water pumps. An optimal design procedure was developed to determine system configurations so as to achieve efficiency and power density metrics while minimizing cost. The final design would achieve a thermodynamic efficiency of 92% and complete a 7bar-200bar compression within one second. This would more than double the power density and lower the expected system cost compared to a previous design. Overall, 2 orders of magnitude improvement in power-density over conventional air-compressor without heat transfer augmentation is achieved.  

To implement the design, various subsystems were developed including custom-designed electric control air valves and a novel water-level sensor for measuring the instantaneous position of the liquid piston within the compression chamber. A functional prototype of the near isothermal compressor/expander has been developed and basic functionality has been experimentally demonstrated. 

Successful development and commercialization of an efficient and high-power air compressor/expander can enable isothermal Compressed Air Energy Storage (i-CAES) to become an economical energy storage option for the electrical grid. The same technology can also be used for improving the energy efficiency of compressing industrial gas or other gas such as Carbon Dioxide for sequestration that currently requires a significant amount of energy.


 

 


Last Modified: 07/08/2022
Modified by: Perry Y Li
